summary: This document provides an overview of Jeffrey Epstein's source of wealth, detailing his career trajectory from working at Bear Stearns to founding his own financial management firm, J. Epstein & Co. It highlights key relationships with notable figures and mentions his criminal conviction for soliciting an underage girl for prostitution.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is the central figure in the document, described as a financier and registered sex offender with a significant career in finance.

connections.description: Wexner is a well-known client of Epstein's financial management firm.
Epstein and Zuckerman were equal partners in financing the magazine Radar.
Greenberg's son was a student of Epstein at the Dalton School.
Wasserstein outbid Epstein for the acquisition of New York magazine.
Roshan retained a small ownership stake in Radar, which was financed by Epstein and Zuckerman.

events.title: Conviction for Soliciting an Underage Girl
events.description: Epstein was convicted of soliciting an underage girl for prostitution and served 13 months in prison.

events.title: Founding of J. Epstein & Co.
events.description: Epstein founded his own financial management firm, managing assets for high-net-worth clients.

events.title: Renaming of Firm to Financial Trust Company
events.description: Epstein changed the name of his firm to Financial Trust Company and relocated it to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

events.title: Financing of Radar Magazine
events.description: Epstein and Zuckerman committed up to $25 million to finance Radar magazine.

events.title: Bid for New York Magazine
events.description: Epstein bid to acquire New York magazine but was ultimately outbid.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in 2008 for soliciting an underage girl for prostitution.
Epstein founded his financial management firm, J. Epstein & Co., in 1982.
Leslie Wexner became a notable client of Epstein's firm.
Epstein and Mortimer Zuckerman financed Radar magazine together.
Epstein attempted to acquire New York magazine in 2003 but was outbid.
